In 2004 faculty members from the School of Nursing at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas began an initiative to preserve the history of nursing and nurses in Southern Nevada. The project was primarily led by faculty member Dr. Margaret Louis with assistance from Maureen Matteson-Kane, Patricia Van Betten, and other volunteers. Oral history interviews were conducted with nurses who have practiced in Southern Nevada. UNLV School of Nursing faculty members and former students were also interviewed.

The History of Nursing in Southern Nevada Oral History Project Records (1965-2014) are comprised of material related to a volunteer project initiative at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas School of Nursing to conduct oral history interviews with nurses who have practiced in Southern Nevada. The collection contains subject files related to the project, as well as audio, video, and transcript files for the interviews. In addition, there are photographs, news clippings, event programs, and certificates from nurses in the region, many of whom were also interviewed. The collection also includes general information on nursing in Southern Nevada such as research papers and documents from the Nevada Nurses Association.

The Homer Rissman Papers (1957-2001) consist of contracts, designs, and plans of architect Homer Rissman. The majority of the designs pertain to Las Vegas, Nevada hotels and casinos.

Homer Rissman was born in 1927 in Chicago, Illinois, the son of an architect. He attended the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago and started his own practice in 1949, designing now highly sought-after examples of Mid-Century row houses and townhouses in the Lakeview neighborhood of Chicago. After the Korean War and the collapse of new housing construction, his friend James Efston of Efstonbuilt Company invited Rissman to California to remodel the coffee shop and drugstore of the Wilton Hotel in Long Beach. His association with Efston, who was developing plans for a hotel in Las Vegas, Nevada, led to Rissman’s designing his first Las Vegas hotel, the Lady Luck, which eventually opened as the Hacienda in 1956. Through Efston’s contacts in the restaurant business, Rissman began designing restaurants and motels in the local Southern California highway style, in which his colleague Martin Stern was also learning to incorporate new forms for new uses. Like Stern, Rissman developed long-standing associations with hotel chains in California and Nevada. Once established as a Las Vegas hotel architect, Rissman found steady work expanding and renovating Strip hotels and country clubs including the Hacienda, Tropicana, Dunes, Tally Ho, Castaway's and the Silver Slipper. His next major projects were the total redesign and rebuilding of the Frontier Hotel in 1966, and the Bonanza in 1967. In 1968, in association with Las Vegas developer Jay Sarno, Rissman created the original circus tent concept for the iconic Circus, Circus Casino. Rissman was also well-known for the Flamingo Hilton Hotel. Rissman conducted renovations and expansions of existing hotels, including those of his colleague Martin Stern. He added room wings to Stern’s original International Hotel. He also created the plans for Sheldon Adelson’s new Sands Expo and Convention Center in 1989. Both Rissman and Stern developed plans and designs for Binion’s Horseshoe, the Thunderbird and Silverbird, and unrealized proposals for the Aladdin and Landmark Hotels. Stern, as Harrah’s architect, did the redesign of Rissman’s Holiday Casino when it was acquired by Harrah’s. Rissman was also a prominent architect of Primm, Nevada, where he designed Whiskey Pete’s, the Primadonna, and Buffalo Bill's. He also designed the Las Vegas luxury apartment complex Regency Towers, in which he and his wife resided. Homer Rissman died in Las Vegas in 2001.
